problem.prob_desc:
27. 실수 $t$에 대하여 원점을 지나고 곡선 $y=\dfrac{1}{e^x}+e^t$에 접하는 직선의 기울기를 $f(t)$라 하자. $f(a)=-e\sqrt{e}$를 만족시키는 상수 $a$에 대하여 $f'(a)$의 값은? [3점]
① $-\dfrac{1}{3} e\sqrt{e}$ ② $-\dfrac{1}{2}e\sqrt{e}$ ③ $-\dfrac{2}{3}e\sqrt{e}$ ④ $-\dfrac{5}{6}e\sqrt{e}$ ⑤ $-e\sqrt{e}$

gpt-5-codex.title: Tangent condition equation
gpt-5-codex.body: For the curve y = e^{-x} + e^{t}, a tangent line at x = x(t) has slope m = -e^{-x(t)}. Since the tangent passes through the origin, substituting (0,0) into the tangent line equation yields e^{-x(t)} + e^{t} = -x(t) e^{-x(t)}. Multiplying both sides by e^{x(t)} gives the defining relation g(t, x) = x + e^{t+x} + 1 = 0 that links the tangency abscissa x(t) and the parameter t.

gpt-5-codex.title: Solve for parameter a
gpt-5-codex.body: The condition f(a) = -e\sqrt{e} implies -e^{-x(a)} = -e\sqrt{e}, so e^{-x(a)} = e^{3/2}, hence x(a) = -3/2. Substituting x = -3/2 into g(t, x) = 0 gives -3/2 + e^{t-3/2} + 1 = 0, so e^{t-3/2} = 1/2 and a = 3/2 - \ln 2.

gpt-5-codex.title: Differentiate and evaluate f'(a)
gpt-5-codex.body: Differentiating g(t, x(t)) = 0 with respect to t yields e^{t+x} + (1 + e^{t+x}) x'(t) = 0, so x'(t) = -e^{t+x} / (1 + e^{t+x}). Then f'(t) = e^{-x(t)} x'(t). At t = a, e^{t+x} = 1/2 and e^{-x} = e^{3/2}, giving x'(a) = -(1/2)/(1+1/2) = -1/3 and thus f'(a) = e^{3/2}(-1/3) = -(1/3) e\sqrt{e}.

gpt-5.title: Set tangency conditions
gpt-5.body: Let the tangency point be x. For y = e^{-x} + e^t, derivative is y' = -e^{-x}. A line through origin tangent at x must satisfy: (i) slope m = y'(x) = -e^{-x}, (ii) y(x) = m x ⇒ e^{-x} + e^t = m x. Using m = -e^{-x}, we get e^{-x} + e^t = -e^{-x} x ⇒ e^t = -(x+1)e^{-x} (requires x < -1).

gpt-5.title: Parameterize by x
gpt-5.body: Define m(x) = -e^{-x}, t(x) = ln(e^t) = ln( -(x+1)e^{-x} ) = ln( -(x+1) ) - x (valid for x < -1). Then f(t(x)) = m(x).

gpt-5.title: Differentiate via chain rule
gpt-5.body: Compute dm/dx = e^{-x}. Compute dt/dx = d/dx[ln( -(x+1) ) - x] = 1/(x+1) - 1. Thus f'(t) = dm/dt = (dm/dx)/(dt/dx) = e^{-x} / (1/(x+1) - 1).

claude-opus-4.5.title: Set up the tangent line condition
claude-opus-4.5.body:
The curve is $y = e^{-x} + e^t$. Let the tangent point be $(p, e^{-p} + e^t)$.

The derivative is $y' = -e^{-x}$, so the slope at point $p$ is $-e^{-p}$.

Since the tangent line passes through the origin, we have:
$$\frac{e^{-p} + e^t - 0}{p - 0} = -e^{-p}$$

This gives us: $e^{-p} + e^t = -pe^{-p}$

claude-opus-4.5.title: Express the relationship between p and t
claude-opus-4.5.body:
From $e^{-p} + e^t = -pe^{-p}$:
$$e^t = -pe^{-p} - e^{-p} = -(p+1)e^{-p}$$

For this to have a solution (since $e^t > 0$), we need $-(p+1)e^{-p} > 0$, which means $p < -1$.

So: $e^t = -(p+1)e^{-p}$

The slope function is: $f(t) = -e^{-p}$

claude-opus-4.5.title: Differentiate to find f'(t)
claude-opus-4.5.body:
From $e^t = -(p+1)e^{-p}$, differentiate both sides with respect to $t$:
$$e^t = -(p+1)e^{-p}$$

Differentiating: $e^t \cdot 1 = -[p' \cdot e^{-p} + (p+1) \cdot (-e^{-p}) \cdot p']$
$$e^t = -p'e^{-p} + (p+1)e^{-p}p'$$
$$e^t = p'e^{-p}[-1 + (p+1)]$$
$$e^t = p'e^{-p} \cdot p$$
$$p' = \frac{e^t}{pe^{-p}} = \frac{e^t \cdot e^p}{p}$$

Since $f(t) = -e^{-p}$:
$$f'(t) = -e^{-p} \cdot (-p') = e^{-p} \cdot p' = e^{-p} \cdot \frac{e^t \cdot e^p}{p} = \frac{e^t}{p}$$

gemini-3-pro.title: Set up tangency equations
gemini-3-pro.body: Let the x-coordinate of the point of tangency be $s$. The derivative of the curve $y = e^{-x} + e^t$ with respect to $x$ is $y' = -e^{-x}$. The slope of the tangent line is $f(t) = -e^{-s}$. Since the tangent line passes through the origin $(0,0)$ and the point $(s, e^{-s}+e^t)$, the slope is also given by $\frac{e^{-s}+e^t - 0}{s - 0}$. Equating the slopes: $-e^{-s} = \frac{e^{-s}+e^t}{s}$. Simplifying this yields $e^t = -e^{-s}(1+s)$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Find the value of s at t=a
gemini-3-pro.body: We are given $f(a) = -e\sqrt{e} = -e^{3/2}$. Using the slope formula $f(t) = -e^{-s}$, we have $-e^{-s} = -e^{3/2}$, which implies $e^{-s} = e^{3/2}$. Taking the natural logarithm of both sides gives $-s = 3/2$, so $s = -\frac{3}{2}$ when $t=a$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Calculate e^a
gemini-3-pro.body:
Substitute $s = -\frac{3}{2}$ into the relation $e^t = -e^{-s}(1+s)$ derived in Step 0. At $t=a$, we have:
$e^a = -e^{-(-3/2)}(1 - \frac{3}{2}) = -e^{3/2}(-\frac{1}{2}) = \frac{1}{2}e^{3/2}$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Derive expression for f'(t)
gemini-3-pro.body:
Since $f(t) = -e^{-s}$, we differentiate with respect to $t$ using the chain rule: $f'(t) = e^{-s} \frac{ds}{dt}$. To find $\frac{ds}{dt}$, differentiate the implicit relation $e^t = -e^{-s}(1+s)$ with respect to $t$:
$e^t = \frac{d}{ds}[-e^{-s}(1+s)] \frac{ds}{dt} = [e^{-s}(1+s) - e^{-s}] \frac{ds}{dt} = s e^{-s} \frac{ds}{dt}$.
Thus, $\frac{ds}{dt} = \frac{e^t}{s e^{-s}}$.
Substituting this back into the expression for $f'(t)$, we get $f'(t) = e^{-s} \left( \frac{e^t}{s e^{-s}} \right) = \frac{e^t}{s}$.

gemini-3-pro.title: Evaluate f'(a)
gemini-3-pro.body:
Substitute $s = -\frac{3}{2}$ and $e^a = \frac{1}{2}e^{3/2}$ into the derived formula $f'(a) = \frac{e^a}{s}$:
$f'(a) = \frac{\frac{1}{2}e^{3/2}}{-\frac{3}{2}} = \frac{1}{2}e^{3/2} \cdot \left(-\frac{2}{3}\right) = -\frac{1}{3}e^{3/2} = -\frac{1}{3}e\sqrt{e}$.

grok-4-fast.title: Define curve and tangent condition
grok-4-fast.body: The curve is \( y(x) = e^{-x} + e^t \). The derivative is \( y'(x) = -e^{-x} \). Let the point of tangency be \( x_0 \), so slope \( m = -e^{-x_0} \). Let \( k = e^{-x_0} > 0 \), then \( m = -k \) and \( x_0 = -\ln k \). The y-coordinate at \( x_0 \) is \( y(x_0) = k + e^t \). The tangent line passes through (0,0), so \( y(x_0) = m x_0 \), which gives \( k + e^t = -k (-\ln k) = k \ln k \). Thus, \( e^t = k(\ln k - 1) \). Since \( f(t) = m = -k \), \( k \) satisfies this equation implicitly.

grok-4-fast.title: Use given f(a) to find k_a
Differentiate to find f'(t)
grok-4-fast.body: Let \( g(k) = k(\ln k - 1) \), so \( e^t = g(k) \) and \( f(t) = -k \). Differentiate implicitly: \( e^t = g'(k) k' \), where \( g'(k) = \ln k \). Thus, \( k' = e^t / \ln k \) and \( f'(t) = -k' = -e^t / \ln k \).
